channel.title: file_event on My New Hugo Site
channel.description: Recent content in file_event on My New Hugo Site

item.title: Suspicious MSExchangeMailboxReplication ASPX Write
item.description: Detects suspicious activity in which the MSExchangeMailboxReplication process writes .asp and .apsx files to disk, which could be a sign of ProxyShell exploitation

item.title: GoToAssist Temporary Installation Artefact
item.description: An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks. These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment. Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

item.title: ScreenConnect Temporary Installation Artefact
item.description: An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks. These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment. Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

item.title: Anydesk Temporary Artefact
item.description: An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks. These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment. Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

item.title: ISO or Image Mount Indicator in Recent Files
item.description: Detects the creation of recent element file that points to an .ISO, .IMG, .VHD or .VHDX file as often used in phishing attacks. This can be a false positive on server systems but on workstations users should rarely mount .iso or .img files.

item.title: TeamViewer Remote Session
item.description: Detects the creation of log files during a TeamViewer remote session

item.title: Installation of TeamViewer Desktop
item.description: TeamViewer_Desktop.exe is create during install

item.title: Suspicious Creation with Colorcpl
item.description: Once executed, colorcpl.exe will copy the arbitrary file to c:\windows\system32\spool\drivers\color\

item.title: Suspicious Process Writes Ntds.dit
item.description: Detects suspicious processes that write (copy) a Active Directory database (ntds.dit) file

item.title: Creation Exe for Service with Unquoted Path
item.description: Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking vulnerable file path references. Adversaries can take advantage of paths that lack surrounding quotations by placing an executable in a higher level directory within the path, so that Windows will choose the adversary’s executable to launch.

item.title: New Shim Database Created in the Default Directory
item.description: Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims. The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time.

item.title: Suspicious Screensaver Binary File Creation
item.description: Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity. Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension

item.title: Suspicious Creation TXT File in User Desktop
item.description: Ransomware create txt file in the user Desktop

item.title: Mimikatz MemSSP Default Log File Creation
item.description: Detects Mimikatz MemSSP default log file creation

item.title: Suspicious Unattend.xml File Access
item.description: Attempts to access unattend.xml, where credentials are commonly stored, within the Panther directory where installation logs are stored. If these files exist, their contents will be displayed. They are used to store credentials/answers during the unattended windows install process

item.title: NPPSpy Hacktool Usage
item.description: Detects the use of NPPSpy hacktool that stores cleartext passwords of users that logged in to a local file

item.title: InstallerFileTakeOver LPE CVE-2021-41379 File Create Event
item.description: Detects signs of the exploitation of LPE CVE-2021-41379 that include an msiexec process that creates an elevation_service.exe file

item.title: Windows Shell File Write to Suspicious Folder
item.description: Detects a Windows executable that writes files to suspicious folders

item.title: Suspicious Scheduled Task Write to System32 Tasks
item.description: Detects the creation of tasks from processes executed from suspicious locations

item.title: Suspicious VHD Image Download From Browser
item.description: Malware can use mountable Virtual Hard Disk .vhd file to encapsulate payloads and evade security controls

item.title: PowerShell Writing Startup Shortcuts
item.description: Attempts to detect PowerShell writing startup shortcuts. This procedure was highlighted in Red Canary Intel Insights Oct. 2021, “We frequently observe adversaries using PowerShell to write malicious .lnk files into the startup directory to establish persistence. Accordingly, this detection opportunity is likely to identify persistence mechanisms in multiple threats. In the context of Yellow Cockatoo, this persistence mechanism eventually launches the command-line script that leads to the installation of a malicious DLL”

item.title: Suspicious Word Cab File Write CVE-2021-40444
item.description: Detects file creation patterns noticeable during the exploitation of CVE-2021-40444

item.title: UAC Bypass Abusing Winsat Path Parsing - File
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using a path parsing issue in winsat.exe (UACMe 52)

item.title: UAC Bypass Using .NET Code Profiler on MMC
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using .NET Code Profiler and mmc.exe DLL hijacking (UACMe 39)

item.title: UAC Bypass Using Consent and Comctl32 - File
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using consent.exe and comctl32.dll (UACMe 22)

item.title: UAC Bypass Using IEInstal - File
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using IEInstal.exe (UACMe 64)

item.title: UAC Bypass Using MSConfig Token Modification - File
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using a msconfig GUI hack (UACMe 55)

item.title: UAC Bypass Using NTFS Reparse Point - File
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using NTFS reparse point and wusa.exe DLL hijacking (UACMe 36)

item.title: UAC Bypass Using Windows Media Player - File
item.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using Windows Media Player osksupport.dll (UACMe 32)

item.title: Created Files by Office Applications
item.description: This rule will monitor executable and script file creation by office applications. Please add more file extensions or magic bytes to the logic of your choice.

item.title: Powerup Write Hijack DLL
item.description: Powerup tool’s Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation. In it’s default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command. The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

item.title: CVE-2021-31979 CVE-2021-33771 Exploits by Sourgum
item.description: Detects patterns as noticed in exploitation of Windows CVE-2021-31979 CVE-2021-33771 vulnerability and DevilsTongue malware by threat group Sourgum

item.title: Suspicious ADSI-Cache Usage By Unknown Tool
item.description: Detects the usage of ADSI (LDAP) operations by tools. This may also detect tools like LDAPFragger.

item.title: Suspicious desktop.ini Action
item.description: Detects unusual processes accessing desktop.ini, which can be leveraged to alter how Explorer displays a folder’s content (i.e. renaming files) without changing them on disk.

item.title: Powershell Profile.ps1 Modification
item.description: Detects a change in profile.ps1 of the Powershell profile

item.title: File Created with System Process Name
item.description: Detects the creation of an executable with a system process name in a suspicious folder

item.title: Detection of SafetyKatz
item.description: Detects possible SafetyKatz Behaviour

item.title: QuarksPwDump Dump File
item.description: Detects a dump file written by QuarksPwDump password dumper

item.title: CVE-2021-1675 Print Spooler Exploitation Filename Pattern
item.description: Detects the default filename used in PoC code against print spooler vulnerability CVE-2021-1675

item.title: CVE-2021-26858 Exchange Exploitation
item.description: Detects possible successful exploitation for vulnerability described in CVE-2021-26858 by looking for | creation of non-standard files on disk by Exchange Server’s Unified Messaging service | which could indicate dropping web shells or other malicious content

item.title: Dynamic C Sharp Compile Artefact
item.description: When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process. Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk. This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

item.title: Hijack Legit RDP Session to Move Laterally
item.description: Detects the usage of tsclient share to place a backdoor on the RDP source machine’s startup folder

item.title: LSASS Memory Dump File Creation
item.description: LSASS memory dump creation using operating systems utilities. Procdump will use process name in output file if no name is specified

item.title: Malicious PowerShell Commandlet Names
item.description: Detects the creation of known powershell scripts for exploitation

item.title: Microsoft Office Add-In Loading
item.description: Detects add-ins that load when Microsoft Word or Excel starts (.wll/.xll are simply .dll fit for Word or Excel).

item.title: Mimikatz Kirbi File Creation
item.description: Detects the creation of files that contain Kerberos tickets based on an extension used by the popular tool Mimikatz

item.title: Octopus Scanner Malware
item.description: Detects Octopus Scanner Malware.

item.title: Outlook C2 Macro Creation
item.description: Detects the creation of a macro file for Outlook. Goes with win_outlook_c2_registry_key. VbaProject.OTM is explicitly mentioned in T1137. Particularly interesting if both events Registry & File Creation happens at the same time.

item.title: Outlook Form Installation
item.description: Detects the creation of new Outlook form which can contain malicious code

item.title: PCRE.NET Package Temp Files
item.description: Detects processes creating temp files related to PCRE.NET package

item.title: Pingback Backdoor
item.description: Detects the use of Pingback backdoor that creates ICMP tunnel for C2 as described in the trustwave report

item.title: Rclone Config File Creation
item.description: Detects Rclone config file being created

item.title: RedMimicry Winnti Playbook Dropped File
item.description: Detects actions caused by the RedMimicry Winnti playbook

item.title: Startup Folder File Write
item.description: A General detection for files being created in the Windows startup directory. This could be an indicator of persistence.

item.title: Suspcious CLR Logs Creation
item.description: Detects suspicious .NET assembly executions. Could detect using Cobalt Strike’s command execute-assembly.

item.title: Suspicious Desktopimgdownldr Target File
item.description: Detects a suspicious Microsoft desktopimgdownldr file creation that stores a file to a suspicious location or contains a file with a suspicious extension

item.title: Suspicious Interactive PowerShell as SYSTEM
item.description: Detects the creation of files that indicator an interactive use of PowerShell in the SYSTEM user context

item.title: Suspicious PFX File Creation
item.description: A general detection for processes creating PFX files. This could be an indicator of an adversary exporting a local certificate to a PFX file.

item.title: Suspicious PROCEXP152.sys File Created In TMP
item.description: Detects the creation of the PROCEXP152.sys file in the application-data local temporary folder. This driver is used by Sysinternals Process Explorer but also by KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU) or Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU.

item.title: WMI Persistence - Script Event Consumer File Write
item.description: Detects file writes of WMI script event consumer

item.title: Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack
item.description: Detects a threat actor creating a file named wbemcomn.dll in the C:\Windows\System32\wbem\ directory over the network and loading it for a WMI DLL Hijack scenario.

item.title: Writing Local Admin Share
item.description: Aversaries may use to interact with a remote network share using Server Message Block (SMB). This technique is used by post-exploitation frameworks.
